text:
A federal appeals court has preserved partial 
access to the abortion pill mifepristone.

And California Sen. Dianne 
Feinstein will temporarily
step down from the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Good morning, I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

A federal appeals court panel in New 
Orleans has preserved access to the
abortion pill mifepristone, but NPR's Dave Mystic

says the appeals court panel is imposing 
stricter rules to obtain the medication:

"A ruling last week by a judge in Texas blocked 
the FDA's decadeslong approval of mifepristone.

The case was brought by opponents of abortion 
rights, but the Biden administration appealed that

decision, and now a three-judge panel has allowed 
the drug to continue to be dispensed up to seven

weeks of pregnancy, scaling it back from 10 weeks, 
and not by mail. NPR's Dave Mystic reporting."

Southeast Florida is recovering from an 
astonishing storm yesterday. More than a

foot of rain fell on Fort Lauderdale. Some nearby 
places got more than 20 inch inches in just a

few hours. Broward County, Florida, schools are 
closed today, and the runways at Fort Lauderdale's

airport could not be used. They were underwater. 
The city is under an emergency declaration.

California Democratic Sen. Dianne Feinstein 
is facing some calls from members of her

party to resign. Feinstein has been away 
from the Senate for more than a month,

recovering from shingles. From member 
station KQED, Scott Schaefer reports:

"The 89-year-old is asking for a temporary 
replacement on the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Feinstein said in a statement that she's asked 
Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer to name

another Democrat to take her spot on the Judiciary 
Committee for now. Feinstein's absence for the

last six weeks has left Democrats on the committee 
unable to move President Biden's judicial nominees

to the full Senate. Jessica Levinson, from Loyola 
Law School in LA, says time is of the essence for

Democrats: 'There always is a clock when it comes 
to judicial nominees, and as more time goes by,

it becomes more politically difficult.' Rep. 
Ro Khanna, of California, and other Democrats

have called on Feinstein to resign from her 
seat, but the 89-year-old senator says she

intends to return after she recovers. For NPR 
News, I'm Scott Schaefer in San Francisco."

President Biden addresses 
the Irish Parliament today,

the latest stop on his visit to the Republic 
of Ireland and Northern Ireland. NPR's Frank

Langfitt reports from Dublin, Biden 
is also focusing on his Irish roots:

"Biden visited a castle along the coast 
yesterday where his great-great-grandfather

on his mother's side, Owen Finnegan, sailed 
with his family to New York in 1849. Later,

the president spoke at a pub in the city of 
Dundalk of his connection to the land of his

ancestors: 'Coming here feels like coming home, 
and it really does — the way, every time I've come,

the welcome, the people on the streets, they're 
just so, so gracious to us.' On Friday, Biden

travels to County Mayo. He'll speak at a cathedral 
in Balina, where his great-great-great-grandfather,

Edward Blewett, supplied thousands of 
bricks for its construction before he,

too, sailed with his family to America during the 
Irish famine. Frank Langfitt, NPR News, Dublin."
This is NPR.
